title: Dave Valentine
text:
David Donald Valentine (12 September 1926 – 14 August 1976) was a Scottish representative <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> and <a href="Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a> winning <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer, a <a href="List%20of%20dual-code%20rugby%20internationals">dual-code rugby international</a> who played in the 1940s and 1950s, and <a href="Coach%20%28sport%29">coach</a>ed in the 1960s.
Rugby union.
He made his <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> international début as a flanker for <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> against <a href="Ireland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Ireland</a> in the <a href="1947%20Five%20Nations%20Championship">1947 Five Nations Championship</a>, and was also selected in the fixture that year against <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a>.
His younger brother <a href="Alec%20Valentine">Alec Valentine</a> also played for , and his younger brother <a href="Rob%20Valentine%20%28rugby%29">Rob</a> played rugby union for South of Scotland, and later switched to rugby league playing for Great Britain.
In October 1947 Valentine signed to play <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> with English club Huddersfield, where he would join another five ex-Hawick players.
Rugby league.
Valentine's <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> career was with the <a href="Huddersfield%20Giants">Huddersfield</a> club where he played as a Loose forward. He played in all three Tests of the 1948–49 victorious <a href="Rugby%20League%20Ashes">Ashes</a> series.
He played for the <a href="British%20Empire%20XIII%20rugby%20league%20team">British Empire XIII</a> versus <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">New Zealand</a> on Wednesday 23 January 1952 at <a href="Stamford%20Bridge%20%28stadium%29">Stamford Bridge</a>, and in the 2nd and 3rd Tests of the 1952 Ashes series.
Dave Valentine played in <a href="Huddersfield%20Giants">Huddersfield</a>'s 15-10 victory over <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a> in the <a href="1952%E2%80%9353%20Challenge%20Cup">1952–53 Challenge Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1952%E2%80%9353%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%23Challenge%20Cup">1952-53 season</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Wembley Stadium</a>, <a href="London">London</a> on Saturday 25 April 1953, in front of a crowd of 89,588.
In 1954 Valentine was selected for <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a>'s tour of <a href="Australian%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Australia</a> playing in all three Tests. He was also the British squad captain for their successful <a href="1954%20Rugby%20League%20World%20Cup">1954 Rugby League World Cup</a> campaign, playing in all four matches and hoisting the Cup as the victorious <a href="Captain%20%28sports%29">captain</a> following Great Britain's 16-12 victory at <a href="Parc%20des%20Princes">Parc des Princes</a> in the Final over <a href="France%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">France</a>, in front of a huge 31, 000 crowd.
Dave Valentine also represented <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a> while at Huddersfield between 1952 and 1956 against France (1 non-<a href="Test%20match%20%28rugby%20league%29">Test match</a>).
All told he earned eleven Test caps in addition to the four World Cup appearances.
Valentine played , and was <a href="Captain%20%28sports%29">captain</a> in <a href="Huddersfield%20Giants">Huddersfield</a>'s 4-11 defeat by <a href="Bradford%20Bulls">Bradford Northern</a> in the <a <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20Cup">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1957%E2%80%9358%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1957–58 season</a> at <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Headingley Rugby Stadium</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a> on Saturday 29 October 1960.
Valentine's <a href="Testimonial%20match">Testimonial match</a> at <a href="Huddersfield%20Giants">Huddersfield</a> took place in 1956. He retired in 1957, having made 356 appearances for Huddersfield.
His grandson, also called Dave Valentine, plays for amateur rugby league club Lindley Swifts.
Coaching career.
Dave Valentine was the <a href="Coach%20%28sport%29">coach</a> in <a href="Huddersfield%20Giants">Huddersfield</a>'s 6-12 defeat by <a href="Wakefield%20Trinity">Wakefield Trinity</a> in the <a href="1961%E2%80%9362%20Challenge%20Cup">1961–62 Challenge Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1961%E2%80%9362%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%23Challenge%20Cup">1961–62 season</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Wembley Stadium</a>, <a href="London">London</a> on Saturday 12 May 1962, in front of a crowd of 81,263, and was the <a href="Coach%20%28sport%29">coach</a> in the 14-5 victory over <a href="Wakefield%20Trinity">Wakefield Trinity</a> in the <a href="Rugby%20Football%20League%20Championship">Championship</a> Final during the <a href="1961%E2%80%9362%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season%23Challenge%20Cup">1961–62 season</a> at <a href="Odsal%20Stadium">Odsal Stadium</a>, <a href="Bradford">Bradford</a> on Saturday 19 May 1962.
Club career.
Dave Valentine was the coach of <a href="Batley%20Bulldogs">Batley</a> from June 1966 to December 1967.
Post-playing.
Since 2004, the management of the <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Scotland national rugby league team</a> have given the Dave Valentine Award to their player of the year.
<a href="Arriva%20Yorkshire">Arriva Yorkshire</a> honoured 13 rugby league footballers on Thursday 20 August 2009, at a ceremony at <a href="The%20Jungle%20%28Wheldon%20Road%29">Wheldon Road</a>, the home of the <a href="Castleford%20Tigers">Castleford</a>. A fleet of new buses were named after the 'Arriva Yorkshire Rugby League Dream Team'. Members of the public nominated the best ever rugby league footballers to have played in West Yorkshire, supported by local rugby league journalists; <a href="BBC%20Radio%20Leeds%23Sport">James Deighton</a> from BBC Leeds, and Tim Butcher, editor of <a href="Rugby%20League%20World">Rugby League World</a>. The 'Arriva Yorkshire Rugby League Dream Team' is; <a href="Trevor%20Foster">Trevor Foster</a> <a href="Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">MBE</a>, <a href="Neil%20Fox%20%28rugby%20league%29">Neil Fox</a> <a href="Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">MBE</a>, <a href="Albert%20Goldthorpe">Albert Goldthorpe</a>, <a href="Alan%20Hardisty">Alan Hardisty</a>, <a href="Stan%20Kielty">Stan Kielty</a>, <a href="Lewis%20Jones%20%28rugby%29">Lewis Jones</a>, <a href="Roger%20Millward">Roger Millward</a> <a href="Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">MBE</a>, <a href="Mal%20Reilly">Malcolm Reilly</a>, <a href="Garry%20Schofield">Garry Schofield</a>, <a href="Keith%20Senior">Keith Senior</a>, <a href="David%20Topliss">David Topliss</a>, Dave Valentine, and <a href="Adrian%20Vowles">Adrian Vowles</a>.
